item.title: Mutual UFO Network
item.description:
Mutual UFO Network ðŸ”—

The Mutual UFO Network (MUFON) is a US-based non-profit organization dedicated to the scientific study of UFOs. Founded in 1969, it has grown to include over 4,000 members worldwide, with chapters in over 43 countries and all 50 US states. MUFON aims to investigate UFO sightings and provide information to the public.

History ðŸ”—

MUFON was originally established as the Midwest UFO Network on May 31, 1969, in Quincy, Illinois, by Allen R. Utke, Walter H. Andrus, Jr., John F. Schuessler, and others. It was renamed the Mutual UFO Network in 1973 due to its expansion. In July 2020, Executive Director Jan Harzan was arrested on charges of soliciting sex from a minor and was subsequently removed from his position.

Operation ðŸ”—

Headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, MUFON has chapters throughout the U.S. and internationally. It hosts an annual international symposium and publishes the monthly MUFON UFO Journal. In 2015, MUFON founded Mutual UFO Network University, an unaccredited online institution for training UFO investigators. The organization has over 500 field investigators who investigate potential physical evidence of extraterrestrial craft.

Criticism ðŸ”—

Pseudoscience ðŸ”—

MUFON has faced criticism for its focus on pseudoscience, including topics like alien abduction, conspiracy theories, and human-ET hybrids. Critics argue that MUFON’s investigations lack scientific rigor and that its researchers are often not scientists.

Officers and donors with far-right viewpoints ðŸ”—

In 2018, Newsweek reported on anti-immigrant, anti-trans, and anti-Muslim sentiments among MUFON officials and donors, including J. Z. Knight and John Ventre. This led to resignations from members like Chris Cogswell and James Clarkson. In 2020, Vice reported that Ken Pfeifer, head of MUFON’s Rhode Island chapter, posted racist content on Facebook.
